Award.AwardTitle: Ergodic Theory of Foliated Spaces through Geometric Deformations
Award.AbstractNarration:
The goal of this project is to develop a set of tools with which to study a large class of dynamical systems. The systems in this large class come from different places, from bouncing balls in polygons to the crystalography of exotic crystals, to name a few. These have been studied using different techniques. The goal here is to show that the systems in this large class have common properties and to develop a point of view which applies to all systems in this class.

More specifically, the proposed project aims at developing a more unified theory of ergodic properties of translation actions on certain foliated spaces. The best known of these systems are translation flows on flat surfaces. A key tool used to study these systems is the use of renormalization flows on moduli spaces obtained through geometric deformations of the foliated spaces. This project seeks to introduce these tools and ideas to the study of the dynamics of other (usually higher rank) translation actions. For example, the subject of quasicrystals, aperiodic tilings and Delone sets is a particularly good one in which to apply the ideas used in Teichm√ºller dynamics. In particular, the relationship between ergodic theory, cohomology, and geometric deformation, which has been exploited in the study of flat surfaces, can also be exploited to study the properties of systems coming from quasicrystals and aperiodic tilings. Tools used in the study of tilings such as non-commutative geometry can also be used to study translation flows on flat surfaces including those of infinite type. This cross-fertilization of fields will be mutually beneficial.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Foliated spaces are a type of mathematical object which makes abstract the concept of layering, although the layers themselves can be of very complicated shapes. Concrete examples that one can have in mind can be found in many foods around the world (see the accompanying images): from the "dragon's beard" of East Asia, whose layers are one-dimensional to the mille feuilles of France and spanakopita of Greece, whose layers are two-dimensional.

Foliated spaces are very useful mathematical objects with which to study all sorts of systems. For example, they can be used to organize the behavior of a particle moving in a polygonal domain, and they can be used to to study spaces of aperiodic tilings which are the mathematical objects used to model exotic physical materials called quasicrystals (see accompanying image). In this project they were used used for both of these purposes. The tool used to study these foliated spaces correspond, roughly speaking and continuing the food analogy, by stretching and kneading the dough in a way that preserves the layered structure. In this setting this deformation is called renormalization.

This project advanced our understanding of higher rank parabolic actions and their connection with other areas such as operator algebras and mathematical physics, in particular through the use of traces. The intellectual merit from this project derives from these advances.

The scientific advances made with the support of this grant have been reported in 4 papers which are under review at international peer-reviewed journals. The PI has disseminated the results of the sponsored research by regularly participating and delivering talks at seminars and conferences. The PI also delivered a set of mini-courses at the 2019 Houston Summer School on Dynamical Systems. The award has also supported the training of young mathematicians as the PI is currently supervising two graduate students. All of this contributes to the broader impacts of the award.
